> For example, a random input node.  Either assign it a random value at
> the beginning of an each activation, or have its value change every time
> it is read.  The network will, of course, evolve to minimize the weights
> to the random node.  But the presence of random fluctuations in the
> environment will force it to adopt a different strategy of execution.

We tried this with our tic-tac-toe player and it didn't seem to make
much difference.  The concept does seem like it could be beneficial to
me, though, especially in domains where the ability to generate
randomness has a clear fitness advantage.  We had thought about using
that if we ever tackle poker.  Even something simpler like prisoner's
dilemma might benefit from a random input node.  It's kind of like
giving the net some dice to roll.

You mentioned an oscillating input node.  That might be useful for
giving the net the concept of the passage of time without giving it an
absolute time input.
